code: # Load required packages library(rnaturalearth) library(ggplot2) library(sf) ## Linking to GEOS 3.10.2, GDAL 3.4.1, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE # Load background information n_a <- ne_states(country = "united states of america", returnclass = "sf") ca <- ne_states(country = "canada", returnclass = "sf") mx <- ne_states(country = "mexico", returnclass = "sf") # Set coordinate system st_crs(hc) <- st_crs(n_a) # Plot ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = n_a) +    geom_sf(data = ca) +   geom_sf(data = hc,           color = '#a75224',           fill = '#C7622B') +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-112, -97), ylim = c(44, 50), expand = FALSE) # Access PBDB API for Edmontosaurus occurrences from the Hell Creek ed <- read.csv("https://paleobiodb.org/data1.2/occs/list.csv?base_name=Edmontosaurus&strat=Hell%20Creek&pgm=gplates,scotese,seton&show=full,strat,lith,ref") # Turn points into spatial features ed_sf <- st_as_sf(x = ed,                                     coords = c("lng", "lat")) # Set coordinate system st_crs(ed_sf) <- st_crs(n_a) st_crs(hc) <- st_crs(n_a) # Plot ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = n_a) +    geom_sf(data = ca) +   geom_sf(data = hc,           color = '#a75224',           fill = '#C7622B') +   geom_sf(data = ed_sf,            color = 'black',            size = 0.7) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-112, -97), ylim = c(44, 50), expand = FALSE) # Load the rphylopic package library(rphylopic) ## You are using rphylopic v.1.4.0. Please remember to credit PhyloPic contributors (hint: `get_attribution()`) and cite rphylopic in your work (hint: `citation("rphylopic")`). # Get an appropriate silhouette for Edmontosaurus ed.uuid <- get_uuid(name = "Edmontosaurus", n = 3)[[3]] # Get the credit for the author of the image get_attribution(uuid = ed.uuid) ## $images ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc` ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$attribution ## [1] "Matt Dempsey" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$contributor ## [1] "Matthew Dempsey" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$contributor_uuid ## [1] "8185ae6d-4d70-4c22-96af-fc8b120cf9cc" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$created ## [1] "2020-05-23" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$contact ## [1] "sketchyraptor93@gmail.com" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$image_uuid ## [1] "72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$license ## [1] "https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/" ##  ## $images$`72be89b9-3f2b-4dc3-b485-e74a5f8b1fbc`$license_abbr ## [1] "CC BY 3.0" # Setup data.frame for the silhouette silhouette_df <- data.frame(x = -99, y = 49.5, name = "Edmontosaurus") # Plot the map ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = n_a) +    geom_sf(data = ca) +   geom_sf(data = hc,           color = '#a75224',           fill = '#C7622B',           lwd = 0) +   geom_sf(data = ed_sf,            color = 'black',            size = 0.7) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-112, -97), ylim = c(44, 50), expand = FALSE) +   geom_phylopic(data = silhouette_df, aes(x = x, y = y),                uuid = ed.uuid,                size = 0.8,                alpha = 1,                color = "black") +   labs(x = "", y = "") # Load `ggpatial` package to add annotations, and `cowplot` to stitch final map  # together library(ggspatial) library(cowplot) # Make an inlay using the country maps we included earlier inset <- n_a %>%    ggplot() +    geom_sf() +   geom_sf(data = ca) +    geom_sf(data = mx) +   geom_rect(xmin = -112, xmax = -97, ymin = 44, ymax = 50,              color = "red", fill = NA) +   xlim(-130, -70) +   ylim(30, 70) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) +   theme_test() +    theme(axis.text = element_blank(),         axis.ticks = element_blank(),         axis.ticks.length = unit(0, "pt"),         axis.title=element_blank(),         plot.margin = margin(0, 0, 0, 0, "cm"),         panel.background = element_rect(fill = "lightblue")) # Add a scale bar and new theme to the original map and save it ed_hc_map <- ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = n_a) +    geom_sf(data = ca) +   geom_sf(data = hc,           color = '#a75224',           fill = '#C7622B',           lwd = 0) +   geom_sf(data = ed_sf,            color = 'black',            size = 0.7) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-112, -97), ylim = c(44, 50), expand = FALSE) +   annotation_scale(location = "br", width_hint = 0.3) +   geom_phylopic(data = silhouette_df, aes(x = x, y = y),                uuid = ed.uuid,                size = 0.8,                alpha = 1,                color = "black") +   labs(x = "", y = "") +   theme_bw() # Plot the two together ggdraw() +   draw_plot(ed_hc_map) +   draw_plot(inset, 0.08, 0.63, width = 0.2, height = 0.2) ## Scale on map varies by more than 10%, scale bar may be inaccurate

text: Quantifying spatiotemporal distribution lithostratigraphic units fundamental understanding environments, associated biodiversity, evolved throughout Earth’s geological history. Previous work theme Peters & Heim (2010) focused “geological completeness paleontological sampling North America” aim recognizing overcoming geologically controlled sampling biases. One element article focused quantifying number proportion different paleoenvironment lithostratigraphic unit types (e.g., marine, marginal, terrestrial) vary time. vignette, revisit theme examine number proportion different lithostratigraphic units–grouped paleoenvironment type–change throughout Phanerozoic. , make use rmacrostrat package fetch data Macrostrat database.

title: The Geological Completeness of Paleontological Sampling in North America
text: quantify number proportion different lithostraphic units change time focus following paleoenvironmental groupings: marine, marginal, terrestrial. first step establishing groupings see different environments actually available Macrostrat: Hint: Remember definitions data stored Macrostrat available via def_ suite functions. call, can see whole suite different inferred paleoenvironments available, conveniently grouped type (e.g., carbonate, fluvial, lacustrine) class (.e., marine non-marine). Class seems helpful defining marine non-marine environments, also want marginal class, need re-classify environment definitions! can define paleoenvironments marginal using additional information available name column environments. definition, let’s consider environment classified delta, beach, barrier island, estuary, lagoon, tidal flat marginal environment. available environments (n = 87), identify 22 marginal environments. classification perhaps little subjective, vignette provides good enough representation marginal environments: Now ’ve classified marginal paleoenvironments, can re-classify class column environments three categories. can also replace non-marine environments terrestrial clarity: Hmmmm lines code getting little long hard read, let’s make simpler create three data.frames, one paleoenvironment. Great! now groupings, want investigate paleoenvironment lithostratigraphic units change time, need little information. Specifically, need know inferred paleoenvironment age specific lithostratigraphic units. can retrieve information lithostratigraphic units using get_units function. Conveniently, can request data paleoenvironment class using environ_id column. Hint: Remember retrieve data stored Macrostrat (e.g., Macrostrat columns, sections, units), get_ suite functions must used. Nice! pretty straight forward. However, notice something weird. unit_id values marine dataframe also present marginal terrestrial dataframes, vice versa: investigation, notice lithostratigraphic units composed multiple paleoenvironments (various combinations marine, marginal, terrestrial). Interesting, expected given transgression regression cycles! treat differently pre-existing groupings clump together different paleoenvironments capture broader information (e.g., terrestrial marine organisms). Let’s make new paleoenvironment class called “mixed”, update environment class accordingly. Great, can now see don’t duplicate units dataset anymore: However, ’ve just remembered Macrostrat doesn’t just cover North America, ’ve pulled units various continents - D’oh! make fairer reproduction Figure 14 Peters & Heim (2010), focus just North America. Conveniently, Macrostrat split different projects, tend cover different regions: call, can see North America project_id 1. can use information filter litho_units: Now ’ve got data done bit wrangling, let’s get summarizing data.
code: # What environments are available? # Hint: Defining no arguments returns all environments environments <- def_environments() # See the first few rows head(environments) ##   environ_id                                 name      type  class   color ## 1          1                            peritidal carbonate marine #B8B8E6 ## 2          2                     shallow subtidal carbonate marine #3399FF ## 3          3                open shallow subtidal carbonate marine #3399FF ## 4          4 lagoonal/restricted shallow subtidal carbonate marine #B8B8E6 ## 5          5                           sand shoal carbonate marine #5CADFF ## 6          6                                 reef carbonate marine #33CCFF ##   t_units ## 1      94 ## 2     815 ## 3     421 ## 4     216 ## 5      25 ## 6     156 # Define an object classifying marginal palaeoenvironments marginal <- c("shallow subtidal", "open shallow subtidal",                "lagoonal/restricted shallow subtidal", "paralic indet.",                "lagoonal", "coastal indet.", "foreshore", "shoreface",               "transition zone/lower shoreface", "barrier bar",               "deltaic indet.", "delta plain", "interdistributary bay",               "delta front", "prodelta", "marginal marine",               "deltaic indet.", "delta plain", "lacustrine deltaic indet.",               "lacustrine delta plain", "lacustrine prodelta", "playa") # Update class to be marginal environments$class[which(environments$name %in% marginal)] <- "marginal" # Let's also change the name of non-marine class to terrestrial environments$class[which(environments$class == "non-marine")] <- "terrestrial" # Subset dataframe marine <- subset(environments, class == "marine") marginal <- subset(environments, class == "marginal") terrestrial <- subset(environments, class == "terrestrial") # Retrieve marine units marine <- get_units(environ_id = marine$environ_id) # Retrieve marginal units marginal <- get_units(environ_id = marginal$environ_id) # Retrieve terrestrial units terrestrial <- get_units(environ_id = terrestrial$environ_id) # Let's also add the environment class in these data.frames for consistency marine$environ_class <- "Marine" marginal$environ_class <- "Marginal" terrestrial$environ_class <- "Terrestrial" # How many marine unit IDs are also in terrestrial? length(which(marine$unit_id %in% terrestrial$unit_id)) ## [1] 499 # What unit IDs are shared between marine, terrestrial, and marginal? shared_id <- c(   # Marine   marine$unit_id[which(marine$unit_id %in% terrestrial$unit_id)],   marine$unit_id[which(marine$unit_id %in% marginal$unit_id)],   # Marginal   marginal$unit_id[which(marginal$unit_id %in% marine$unit_id)],   marginal$unit_id[which(marginal$unit_id %in% terrestrial$unit_id)],   # Terrestrial   terrestrial$unit_id[which(terrestrial$unit_id %in% marine$unit_id)],   terrestrial$unit_id[which(terrestrial$unit_id %in% marginal$unit_id)] ) # Get unique IDs shared_id <- unique(shared_id) # Combine dataframes litho_units <- rbind.data.frame(marine, marginal, terrestrial) # Recode environment class litho_units$environ_class[which(litho_units$unit_id %in% shared_id)] <- "Mixed" # Retain only unique units litho_units <- unique(litho_units) # Check if any units appear more than once any(table(litho_units$unit_id) > 1) ## [1] FALSE # Check available projects def_projects() ##    project_id                   project ## 1           1             North America ## 2           3                      eODP ## 3           4                  Deep Sea ## 4           5               New Zealand ## 5           6                 Australia ## 6           7                 Caribbean ## 7           8             South America ## 8           9                    Africa ## 9          10  North American Ediacaran ## 10         11 North American Cretaceous ## 11         12                 Indonesia ## 12         13          Northern Eurasia ##                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         descrip ## 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Composite column dataset for the USA and Canada. ## 2                                                                   Comprehensive dataset capturing all offshore drilling sites and holes. Holes at each site are captured as 'section' column types and meters below sea floor (mbsf) are encoded by 't_pos' and 'b_pos' when 'show_position' parameter is included. See project_id=3 ('eODP') for complete offshore drilling data and associated measurements. ## 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Primarily measured section-type columns for Late Cretaceous to Recent. ## title: The Geological Completeness of Paleontological Sampling in North America
text: interested number proportion lithostratigraphic units representing different paleoenvironment classes changes time. Conveniently, lithostratigraphic units Macrostrat age information associated , specifically minimum (t_age) maximum (b_age) age millions years present. Using data, handy support functions palaeoverse R package, can count number lithographic units within group, within time bin, time. use international stratigraphic stage bins time bins :
code: # Load palaeoverse R package library(palaeoverse) # Generate stage-level time bins bins <- time_bins(rank = "stage") # Rename age columns in litho_units to be consistent with our bins colnames(litho_units)[which(colnames(litho_units) == "b_age")] <- "max_ma" colnames(litho_units)[which(colnames(litho_units) == "t_age")] <- "min_ma" # As we are only interested in the Phanerozoic, let's remove any # data that has a minimum age of more than 541 Ma  litho_units <- subset(litho_units, min_ma <= 541) # In case the maximum age of units exceeds 541, but the minimum  # age is less than 541, let's set max_ma to 541 to still count it  # if it appears at any point in the Fortunian litho_units$max_ma[which(litho_units$max_ma > 541)] <- 541 # Bin data using the bin_time function with the "all" # method. This will bin units into all bins the unit # overlaps with generating additional rows for each time  # bin (expect an increase in the number of rows) litho_units <- bin_time(occdf = litho_units,                         bins = bins,                         min_ma = "min_ma",                          max_ma = "max_ma",                         method = "all") # Calculate the number of environment classes per bin assignment # Remember, each row is a unique instance of a unit within a bin counts <- group_apply(occdf = litho_units,                        group = c("environ_class", "bin_assignment"),                       fun = nrow) # Rename columns to ease reading and merging colnames(counts) <- c("count", "environment", "bin") # Merge datasets by bin number counts <- merge(x = bins, y = counts, by = "bin")

title: The Geological Completeness of Paleontological Sampling in North America
text: Now summary lithostratigraphic units, can visualise data. Let’s make two plots, one number units within paleoenvironment group time, another proportion units within paleoenvironment group time. support data visualization, make use ggplot2 (plotting) deeptime (adding geological timescale axis) R packages.   ’s ! bad, right? clear differences generated plots, original Peters & Heim (2010) paper (Fig. 14), expected given substantially data now available Macrostrat, may differences define “marginal” environments. Despite differences, broad-scale patterns largely consistent, higher proportion terrestrial lithostratigraphic units Mesozoic Cenozoic, compared Paleozoic. Hopefully vignette shown potential uses rmacrostrat functions helped provide workflow analyses. questions package functionality, please feel free join Palaeoverse Google group leave question; ’ll aim answer soon possible! ’re interested learning rmacrostrat, don’t forget check vignettes! can see ones available calling vignette(package = "rmacrostrat").
code: # Load data visualization packages library(ggplot2) library(deeptime)  # Let's first set our factor levels to replicate the original figure counts$environment <- factor(counts$environment, levels = c("Marine", "Marginal",                                                              "Mixed", "Terrestrial"))  # Generate a plot of raw counts of lithostratigraphic units through time # grouped by paleoenvironment ggplot(counts, aes(fill = environment, y = count, x = mid_ma)) +    # Stacked bar chart with bar width specified by interval duration   geom_bar(position = "stack", stat = "identity", width = counts$duration_myr,            color = "black", linewidth = 0.1) +   # Label y-axis   scale_y_continuous("Number of lithostratigraphic units") +   # Label x-axis and reverse direction   scale_x_reverse("Time (Ma)") +   # Data plotting colors   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   # Theming    theme_bw() +   theme(legend.title = element_blank(),         legend.position = "top") +   # Add geological timescale   coord_geo() # Generate a plot of lithostratigraphic units through time grouped by # paleoenvironment as proportions ggplot(counts, aes(fill = environment, y = count, x = mid_ma)) +    # Proportional bar chart with bar width specified by interval duration   geom_bar(position = "fill", stat = "identity", width = counts$duration_myr,            color = "black", linewidth = 0.1) +   # Label y-axis   scale_y_continuous("Proportion of lithostratigraphic units") +   # Label x-axis and reverse direction   scale_x_reverse("Time (Ma)") +   # Data plotting colors   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   # Theming   theme_bw() +   theme(legend.title = element_blank(),         legend.position = "top") +   # Add geological timescale   coord_geo()

Age millions years present return interval definition . intervals overlapping age returned. age_top numeric. minimum age interval definitions returned, millions years present. specified, age_bottom must also specified, must younger age_bottom. age_bottom numeric. maximum age interval definitions returned, millions years present. specified, age_top must also specified, must older age_top. rule character. interval definitions returned given age_top age_bottom?
